head.title: South Africa Police Disperse Funeral March

hedline.hl1: South Africa Police Disperse Funeral March

body.head.byline: Special to the New York Times

block.p: LEAD: Hundreds of police officers and soldiers used tear gas to disperse mourners and marching students at the funeral of a black youth leader today.
LEAD: Hundreds of police officers and soldiers used tear gas to disperse mourners and marching students at the funeral of a black youth leader today.
Hundreds of police officers and soldiers used tear gas to disperse mourners and marching students at the funeral of a black youth leader today.

The attacks occurred at the funeral of Sicelo Godfrey Dhlomo, an 18-year-old anti-apartheid campaigner who was found shot to death Jan. 24 shortly after being questioned by the police. In December, Mr. Dhlomo's detailed account of maltreatment in police detention was featured in a CBS News program entitled, ''Children of Apartheid.''

The funeral, held at Regina Mundi Roman Catholic Church in Soweto, was one of the most emotional and politically charged events in the black township since a national state of emergency was declared June 1986.

Armed police officers and soldiers in armored vehicles, backed by police helicopters and military spotter planes, mounted a six-hour operation to restrict access to the church. Security forces surrounded the building and frequently entered it, at one point attempting to arrest a black student standing by Mr. Dhlomo's coffin, in full view of the United States Consul General, Peter R. Chaveas, and about a dozen diplomatic representatives.
